titleStmt.title: The mariage of Prince Fredericke, and the Kings daughter, the Lady Elizabeth, vpon Shrouesunday last VVith the shovves on land and water, before, and after the wedding, as also the maskes and reuells in his Highnes court, with the running at the ring, by the Kings Maiestie, the Palsegraue, Prince Charles, and diuers others of the nobilitie.
Marriage of the two great princes, Fredericke Count Palatine, &c: and the Lady Elizabeth, daughter to the Imperial Majesties of King James and Queene Anne.

titleStmt.title: The mariage of Prince Fredericke, and the Kings daughter, the Lady Elizabeth, vpon Shrouesunday last VVith the shovves on land and water, before, and after the wedding, as also the maskes and reuells in his Highnes court, with the running at the ring, by the Kings Maiestie, the Palsegraue, Prince Charles, and diuers others of the nobilitie.
Marriage of the two great princes, Fredericke Count Palatine, &c: and the Lady Elizabeth, daughter to the Imperial Majesties of King James and Queene Anne.

editionStmt.edition: Now the second time imprinted, with many new additions, of the same tryumphs, performed by the gentlemen of the Innes of Court in the Kings pallace of white Hall.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed by T[homas] C[reede] for W. Barley, and are to be sold by W. Wright, at his shop neere S. Pulchers Church, at the signe of the Harrow,

notesStmt.note: An enlarged edition of: The marriage of the two great princes, Fredericke Count Palatine, &c: and the Lady Elizabeth, daughter to the Imperial Majesties of King James and Queene Anne.
The first word of the title is xylographic.
Running title reads: Ioyfull triumphs at the royall mariage.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

keywords.term: Elizabeth, -- Queen, consort of Frederick I, King of Bohemia, 1596-1662.

div.p: THE MARIAGE OF Prince FREDERICKE, and the Kings daughter, the Lady ELIZABETH, vpon Shroue≈øunday la≈øt.

With the showes on land and water, before, and after the wedding, as al≈øo the Maskes and Reuells in his Highnes Court, with the running at the Ring, by the Kings Maie≈øtie, the Pal≈øegraue, Prince Charles, and diuers others of the Nobilitie.
NOW THE SECOND TIME IMPRINTED, with many new additions, of the ≈øame tryumphs, performed by the Gentlemen of the Innes of Court in the Kings Pallace of white Hall.
At London Printed by T. C. for W. Barley, and are to be ≈øold by W. Wright, at his ≈øhop neere S. Pulchers Church, at the ≈øigne of the Harrow, 1613.

div.head: THE MARIAGE OF Prince Fredericke, and the Kings Daughter, the Lady ELIZABETH, vpon Shroue-≈øunday la≈øt.
div.p: BEing de≈øirous to giue ≈øati≈øfaction to certaine of my acquaintance in the countrey, mo≈øt willing to vnder≈øtand the manner of the tryumphes holden at the royall marriage, of his Maie≈øties daughter, Prince≈ø≈øe Elizabeth.
I haue made meanes for the true intelligences thereof, and I hope according to the content of the Reader, I haue ≈øet forth here a true di≈øcour≈øe of the ≈øame.
Fir≈øt, of the ≈øhewes and Fireworkes vpon the waters before the mariage performed, vpon thur≈øday night, being the eleuenth of Februarie.
Then the imitation of a Sea Fight vpon Saterday following.

Al≈øo of the royall and Princely pa≈ø≈øage of Prince Pal≈øegraue with his renowned bride, to his highnes chappell at white Hall, where in the pre≈øence of his Maie≈øtie and the noble ≈øtate, they were married, to make vs reioyce, with a wi≈øhed happines, with the ma≈økes and reuels following, ≈øhewes of more royaltie, then euer in this Age was ≈ø√©ene in the court of England.
Therefore let the Readerd hereof, prepare him≈øelfe, to entertaine them with extraordinarie ioy, and receiue the good will of the writer, for a tribute, to be paide as a dew to his countrey.

div.head: The manner of the fireworkes ≈øhewed vpon the Thames vpon the Thur≈øday before the wedding.
div.p: TO begin the≈øe tryumphant ≈øports, his highnes, the Qu√©enes Maie≈øtie, Prince Charles, Prince Fredericke, with the Princes Elizabeth his royall bride, and the re≈øt of the nobilitie of England, vpon Thur≈øday the eleuenth of Februarie in the euening, being placed in the galleries and windowes about his Highnes Court of white Hall, where in the ≈øight of thou≈øands of people, many artificiall conclu≈øions in Fireworkes were vpon the Thames performed, and that the plea≈øurable ≈øights on the water, might equall the ≈øumptuous ≈øhowes on the land, thus they proc√©eded.

Fir≈øt, for a welcome to the beholders, a peale of ordinance like vnto a terrible thunder ratled in the ayer, and ≈ø√©emed as it were to ≈øhake the earth: Immediately vpon this, a Racket of Fire bur≈øt from the water, and mounted ≈øo high into the Element that it dazeled the beholders eyes to looke after it.

Secondly, followed a number more of the ≈øame fa≈øhion, ≈øpredding ≈øo ≈øtrangely with ≈øparkling blazes, that the ≈økie ≈ø√©emed to be filled with fire, or that there had b√©ene a combate of darting ≈øtarres fighting in the ayre, and all the time the≈øe continued, certaine cannons planted in the fields adioyning made thundring mu≈øicke, to the great plea≈øure of the beholders.

After this in a mo≈øt curious manner, an artificiall fireworke with great wonder was ≈ø√©ene flying in the ayre, like vnto a dragon, again≈øt which an other fierie vi≈øion appeared flaming like to Saint George on Hor≈øebacke, brought in by aburning Inchanter, betw√©ene which was then fought a mo≈øt ≈øtrange battell continuing a quarter of an hower or more: the dragon being vanqui≈øhed, ≈ø√©emed to rore like thunder, and withall bur≈øt in p√©eces and ≈øo vani≈øhed, but the champion with his flaming hor≈øe for a litle time made a ≈øhew of a truimphant conque≈øt, and ≈øo cea≈øed.

After this, was heard an other ratling ≈øound of Cannons, almo≈øt couering the ayre with fire and ≈ømoake, and forthwith appeared out of a hill of earth made vpon the water, a very ≈øtrange fire flaming vpright like vnto a blazing ≈øtarre: After which flew forth a number of rackets ≈øo high in the ayre, that we could not chu≈øe but approue by all rea≈øons that Arte hath exc√©eded Nature, ≈øo artificially were they performed, and ≈øtill as the Chambers and Culuerines plaide vpon the earth, the fireworkes danced in the ayre, to the great delight of his Highnes, and the other Princes.

Out of the ≈øame mount or hill of earth flew an other ≈øtrange p√©ece of artificiall fire-worke, which was in the likenes of a hunted Hart, running vpon the waters ≈øo ≈øwiftly, as it had bene chaced by many hunt≈ømen.

After the ≈øame, i≈ø≈øued out of the mount, a number of hunting hounds made of fire burning, pur≈øuing the afore≈øaid Harte vp and downe the waters, making many rebounds and turnes with much ≈øtrangenes: ≈økipping in the ayre, as it had bene a v≈øuall hunting vpon land.
The≈øe were the noble delights of Princes, and prompt were the wits of men to contriue ≈øuch Princely plea≈øures.
Where Kings commands be, Art is ≈øtretcht to the true depth, as the performance of the≈øe Enginers haue here approued.

But now again to our wi≈øhed ≈øports, when this fiery hunting extingui≈øhed, and that the Elements a little cleared from fire and ≈ømoake, there came ≈øayling vp, as it were vpon the Seas, certaine ≈øhippes and gallies brauely rigd with top and top gallant, with their flagges and ≈øtreamers wauing like men of warre, which repre≈øented a Chri≈øtian Nauie oppo≈øed again≈øt the Turkes, where after they had a while houered, preparing as it were to make an incur≈øion into the Turki≈øh countrey, they were di≈øcouered by two Towers or Ca≈øtles of defence, ≈øtrongly furni≈øhed to intercept all ≈øuch inuading purpo≈øes, ≈øo ≈øending forth the reports of a cannon, they were brauely an≈øwered with the like from the gallies, banding fire and powder one from an other, as if the God of battels had b√©ene there pre≈øent.

Here was the manner of a Sea Fight rightly performed:
Fir≈øt by a≈ø≈øayling one an other, all ≈øtriuing for victorie, and pur≈øuing each other with Fire and ≈øword, the Caluerines merily plaid betwixt them, and made the ayre re≈øound with thundring Ecchoes, and at la≈øt, to repre≈øent the ioyes of a victorie, the Ca≈øtles were ≈øacked, burned and ruinated, and the defenders of the ≈øame forced to e≈øcape with great danger.

During the time of all the≈øe triumphant exerci≈øes, there was not a man vnbu≈øied, but euery one laboured, ≈øome on Land, ≈øome on Water, ≈øome one way, ≈øome an other, to moue his Highnes, and the re≈øt of his princely friends a plea≈øing content, which hee and the other Princes with a gratious acceptance, applauded, to the great comort of the performers, and no litle ioy to the beholders.

The next morning, being Fryday, his Highnes, not intending to grace the following ≈øports with his pre≈øence, gaue cau≈øe of forbearaÃÑce, with ≈øome re≈øt to the Enginers for their great toyle the night before.

Moreouer, it was thought conuenient that a whole dayes preparatioÃÑ ≈øhould be made, in prouiding again≈øt the Saterdayes pa≈øtimes, which moued a more longing de≈øire in the harts of his ≈øubiects to ≈ø√©e the ≈øame, which at the time appointed was in this maner accomplied.

div.head: The manner of a Sea fight, ≈øhewed vpon the Thames, vpon the Saterday before the wedding.
div.p:
BEtw√©ene the howers of two and thr√©e of the clocke the ≈øame day in the after noone being Sroue-≈øaterday, the Kings Maie≈øtie, accompanied with the Qu√©ene, and the re≈øt of the Princes and P√©eres of e≈øtate, to adde the more glory to the≈øe pretended ≈øhowes, placed them≈øelues in great royaltie vpon the priuie ≈øtaires of white Hall, where after a while expecting the beginning of the de≈øired fireworkes, the Lord Admirall ≈øent forth two or thr√©e gentlemen in a whirrie, with a flagge or banner to ≈øignifie the King, and the Nobilities tarriance for the repre≈øentations,
which was an≈øwered with an Intelligence by the report, from a great cannon, whereupon a certaine Vene≈øian man of Warre, and a ≈øhip called a Caruell, came proudly with their flagges and colours ≈øayling vp, in the ≈øight of ≈øeuent√©ene Turki≈øh gallies which lay houering vpon Lambeth ≈øide, betwixt whom was a mo≈øt royall and prai≈øe worthy Imitation of a ≈øea fight in ≈øuch ≈øort performed, as if the danger of ≈øuch an Enterpri≈øe had bene by true action attempted, all which explaines the honors of martiali≈øts, and made his Maie≈øtie, with many thou≈øands of people of all ≈øorts, and of many Nations eye-witne≈ø≈øes of the true manner of ≈øuch like incounters. But not to be trouble≈øome in my di≈øcour≈øes, I will briefly explaine the incounters as they pa≈ø≈øed.

There was a barre or a kind of artificiall fence made vpon the riuer of Thames with Barges and Lighters chained together, to k√©epe out pa≈ø≈øengers, which otherwi≈øe with much vnrulines would haue hindered the pa≈øtimes, and much troubled the performers, but being thus hemde in, as it were vpon the maine Seas, the two Venetian ≈øhippes as I ≈øaid before, falling within danger of the Turki≈øh gallies, indured a fre≈øh encounter, and long time mo≈øt worthily defended them≈øelues, but by rea≈øon of the number of the gallies, they were at la≈øt boarded, taken, and carried as boote and prize vnder the commaund of a Turki≈øh Ca≈øtle, which repre≈øented and bare the name of the ca≈øtle of Argeir, Furni≈øhed with 22. well approued great p√©eces of Ordinance, which was contriued and built vpon Lambeth ≈øide, at a place named Stand-gate, inuironed with craggie Rocks as the ≈øaid Ca≈øtle is now ≈øcituate in Turkie.

After the Gallies had taken the≈øe Venetian ≈øhips, and deliuered them into the Turki≈øh Admiralls commaund, they had ≈øight of an other Argo≈øay or Galliaza, which ≈ø√©emed to be of Spaine, which likewi≈øe after a fierce conflict they made prize of, and with much tryumph rendred the ≈øame vp al≈øo to the Turki≈øh Admirall.

After this, vpon a ≈øuddaine there was a thundring peale of Ordinance or Chambers placed in Lambeth Mar≈øhe, wherevpon the Scoutes and Watches of the Ca≈øtle, di≈øcouered an Engli≈øh
Nauie, to the number of fift√©ene Saile of the Kings Pinnaces, making vp towards the point, with their red cro≈øt Streamers mo≈øt gallantly wauing in the Ayre, to the great delight of all the beholders, which as then ≈øeemed to couer ouer the Thames in Boates and Barges.

Neare vnto this place ≈øtood a high built watch Tower, or Beacon of the Turkes, which at the fir≈øt ≈øight of the Engli≈øh Nauie was ≈øet on fire, as the manner is at all ≈øuch incur≈øions, which blazing Light (as it ≈ø√©emed) gaue notice to the Ca≈øtle, and cau≈øed a readines in the ≈øame for defence: In the meane time, the Kings Pinnaces and the Turki≈øh Gallies ioynde, betwixt whom, were ≈øhowne many ≈øtrange attempts, euen as they had ventured their very liues for their countries ≈øafeties: they ≈øpared neither powder nor pollicie, to ≈øacke one an other, but on both ≈øides be≈øtird them≈øelues ≈øo brauely, that his Highne≈ø≈øe withall the re≈øt of his attendants were therewith much delighted: At la≈øt the Gallies being ouercharged with long and forward incounters of the Engli≈øh Nauie, for refuge and ≈øhelter made new vnto the Ca≈øtle, which began likewi≈øe to play brauely vpon the Engli≈øh, and with their thundering ordinance made as it were the ground to ≈øhake.
The Kings Nauie to an≈øwere them was not backward in a performance, but made the ayre gloomie with fire and ≈ømoake rorering from their lowde mouthed Cannons.

The fight for a time continued fiercely, the victorie leaning to neither ≈øide, either of them attempting to a≈ø≈øault and board each other, but at la≈øt the Gallies being ≈øore bruzed and beaten, began to y√©eld, wherevpon the Engli≈øh Admirall fell downe and ca≈øt anker before the Ca≈øtle, and then ≈øpared not in the be≈øt manner to thunder off their Ordinance, whereat the Turkes y√©elded both Ca≈øtle and Gallies, and ≈øubmitted to the conque≈øt of the Engli≈øh Admirall, who fiered many of the ≈øaid Gallies, ≈øacked the Ca≈øtle, and tooke pri≈øoner the Turki≈øh Admirall, with diuers Ba≈øhawes and other great Turkes, and al≈øo recouered the Venetian and Spani≈øh Shippes, before taken by the Gallies. After the performance of all the≈øe afore≈øaid, the Engli≈øh Admirall, in a mo≈øt tryumphant manner carried as a pri≈øoner, the Admirall
of the Gallies attired in a red Iacket with blew ≈øl√©eues, according to the Turki≈øh fa≈øhion, with the Ba≈øhawes, and the other Turkes, guarded to his Highnes priuie ≈øtaires of white Hall, where his grace, Prince Pal≈øegraue, and his Lady remained, which pri≈øoners were lead by Sir Robert Man≈øfield, to the Lord Admiral, and by him they were conueyed to the Kings Maie≈øtie, as a repre≈øentation of plea≈øure, which to his Highnes moued delight, and highly plea≈øed all there pre≈øent.

All the≈øe afore≈øaid pa≈øtimes were mo≈øt nobly performed betw√©ene the howres of thr√©e and ≈øixe in the after noone, to the great content as well of forraigne nations as of our owne country people, whereof in one place, and at one time, hath bene ≈øeldome ≈ø√©ene a greater number.

Al≈øo for a Farewell to this dayes plea≈øures, a traine of Chambers were di≈øcharged in Saint Georges Field of a long continuance, and of ≈øuch an Ecchoing thunder, that they euen amazed the hearers. Thus ended Saterdayes ≈øhewes vpon the waters, being the eue of this great Mariage-day.

div.head: The manner of the Marriage vpon Shroue-≈øunday, with the Royall pa≈ø≈øage of Prince Fredericke and his Bride to his Maie≈øties Chappell at White-Hall.
div.p: BVt now to relate and make knowne the royall pa≈ø≈øage of the renowmed Bride-groome and his faire Bride, (for the ≈øati≈øfying of many thou≈øands) as they entred into his Highnes Chappell at White-Hall: the next day being Sunday, euen ouercomes me with a reioycing de≈øcription.
The Court being placed full of people of many E≈øtates, ≈øortes, and Nations, and their eyes and hearts fixed to behold the pompious glory of this Marriage in great Royaltie.

Fir≈øt came the Pal≈ø-graue, from the newe built Banquetting-hou≈øe, attired in a white Satten ≈øute, richly be≈øet with Pearle and Golde, attended on by a number of young gallant Courtiers, both Engli≈øh, Scotti≈øh, and Dutch, all in rich manner, euery one ≈øtriuing to exc√©ede in ≈øumptuous habilliaments, fitte
for the attendants of ≈øo princely a Bride-groome. After came the Lady Elizabeth, in her Virgin-robes, clothed in a gowne of white Satten richly embrodered, lead betw√©ene her royall brother Prince Charles, and the Earle of Northampton: vpon her head a crowne of refined golde, made Imperiall (by the Pearles and Dyamonds thereupon placed,) which were ≈øo thicke be≈øet, that they ≈øtood like ≈øhining pinnacles, vpon her amber coloured haire, dependantly hanging plaighted downe ouer her ≈øhoulders to her Wa≈øte, betw√©ene euery plaight a role or li≈øte of Gold-≈øpangles, Pearles, Riche ≈øtones, and Diamonds, and withall, many Diamonds of ine≈øtimable value, imbrothered vpon her ≈øl√©eue, which euen dazeled and amazed the eies of the beholders: her traine in mo≈øt ≈øumptuous manner, carryed vp by fourt√©ene or fift√©ene Ladies, attired in white Satten gownes, adorned with many rich Iewells.

After went a traine of Noble-mens Daughters, in white Ve≈øtements, gloriou≈øly ≈øet foorth: which Virgin Bride-maides attended vpon the Prince≈ø≈øe, like a ≈økye of Cele≈øtiall ≈øtarres, vpon faire Phoebe. After them, came another traine of gallant young Courtiers, flouri≈øhing in ≈øeuerall Sutes, Embrothered and Pearled, who were Knightes, and the ≈øonnes of great Courtiers: After them, came foure Herolds at Armes, in their rich coates of Heroldrie, and then followed many Earles, Lords, and Barrons, as well of Scotland as England, in mo≈øt noble manner, then the king of Herolds, bearing vpon his ≈øhoulder a Mace of golde, and then followed the honourable Lords of his Highnes priuie Councell, which pa≈ø≈øed along after the Traine towards the Chappell, and then came foure reuerend Bi≈øhops of the Land in their Church abilliaments: After them foure Sargiants of the Mace in great ≈øtate, bearing vpon their ≈øhoulders foure rich Enamelled Maces.

Then followed the right Honorable the Earle of Arundell, carrying the Kings Sword: And then in great Royaltie the Kings Maie≈øtie him≈øelfe in a mo≈øt ≈øumptuous blacke ≈øute, with a Dyamond in his hatte of a wonderfull great value; Clo≈øe vnto him came the Qu√©ene, attired in white Satten, beautified with much embrothery, and many Diamonds: Vpon her attended a number
of marryed Ladies, the Counte≈ø≈øes, and wiues of Earles and Barrons, apparelled in mo≈øt noble manner, which added glory vnto this triumphant time and Marriage.

The≈øe were the pa≈ø≈øages of our States of England, accompanying the princely Bride and Bridegroome to his Highnes Chappell, where after the celebration of the Marriage, contracted in the pre≈øence of the King, the Qu√©ene, Prince Charles, and the re≈øt afore≈øaide: they returned into the banquetting hou≈øe with great ioy.

The Lady Elizabeth being thus made a Wife, was led backe, not by two Batchellors as before, but by the Duke of Lineux, and the Earle of Nottingham, in a mo≈øt reuerend manner, before the Pal≈øegraue. At his returne from the chappell, went ≈øixe of his owne Country gallants, clad in crim≈øon Veluet, laide exc√©edingly thicke with gold lace, bearing in their hands sixe ≈øiluer Trumpets, who no ≈øooner comming into the Banquetting hou≈øe, but they pre≈øented him with a melodious ≈øound of the ≈øame, flouri≈øhing ≈øo delightfully, that it greatly reioyced the whole Court, and cau≈øed thou≈øands to ≈øay at that in≈øtant time, God giue them ioy, God giue them ioy.

Thus preparing for dinner, they pa≈ø≈øed away a certaine time, and after fell to Dancing, Ma≈øking, and Reuelling, according to the cu≈øtome of ≈øuch A≈ø≈øemblies, which continued all the day, and part of the night in great plea≈øure.

div.head: The order of the Mundayes ≈øhowes, with the Kings running at the Ring with the Nobilitie of the Land.
div.p: THe next day (being Shroue-munday) by the King and Nobilitie of England was ≈øpent in great honour, where their rich Robes of E≈øtate ≈øeconded the day before, with many commendable graces: for the whole Court ≈øo gloriou≈øly ≈øhined with Imbrothered abilliaments, that it made euen a ≈ømiling ch√©erefulnes ≈øit vpon the countenance of many thou≈øand beholders.

For the Kings Maie≈øtie in his owne per≈øon, accompanied with his braue ≈øpirited ≈øonne Prince Charles of great Brittaine, the Royall Bride-groome, Count Pallatine, the Duke of Linneux, with diuers other of the Earles and Barrons of England and Scotland, together with the prai≈øe-worthy P√©eres of the Netherland Prouinces, performed many famous races at the Ring, an exerci≈øe of much renowne and honour, and the knightly ≈øports, and the Royall delights onely befitting the dignitie of Kings and Princes, and of the chiefe≈øt Nobilitie.

Fir≈øt, about the rayles or li≈øts in the Tylf-yard, adioyning to White Hall, were placed many Herolds at Armes, to beautifie the honourable atchiefements of the≈øe knightly Potentates, and withall, the Knight mar≈øhall of England, and his ≈øeruants, all in new liueries with their ≈øtaues of office, to abate the too forward vnrulines of many di≈øordered people, which otherwi≈øe would haue much troubled the Turnaments, and as an ayde vnto them, many of his Highnes Yoemen of the Guard were attendant in the li≈øtes, and withall, mo≈øt of the Kings Trumpetters in their rich imbrothered coates, the pentioners and Knights of his graces hou≈øhold with their guilded Pole-axes, guarding as it were in a round, the King with his Knightly followers.

The Qu√©enes Maie≈øtie, with her daughter the Princes Elizabeth, attended on by many of the greate≈øt Ladies of the Land, being placed in the Galleries and windowes of the Banquetting hou≈øe, In the pre≈øence of many thou≈øands of his Subiects, the King mounted vpon a St√©ed of much ≈øwiftnes, was the fir≈øt that began the honourable pa≈øtimes, and like a mo≈øt noble martiali≈øt tooke the Ring vpon his ≈øpeare, thr√©e ≈øeuerall times together, whereat the trumpets ≈øtill ≈øounded to the great ioy of all the beholders.

After him the Illu≈øtrious Prince, Count Palatine, vpon a hor≈øe of that braue courage, which ≈ø√©emed to ≈øtand vpon no ground, where with a ≈øpirit of much forwardnes, he tooke the Ring vpon his ≈øpeare twi≈øe together, ≈øo lightly, and ≈øo nimbly, that the whole a≈ø≈øembly gaue him high commendations.

After him, the braue young flower, and hope of England, Prince Charles, mounted as it were vpon a Spani≈øh Iennet, that takes his ≈øwiftnes from ye nature of the winde, mo≈øt couragiou≈øly, and with much agillitie of hand, tooke the Ring clearely foure times in fiue cour≈øes, which was in the eye of the Kings Maie≈øtie and the Nobilitie, there pre≈øent, a ≈øight of much admiration, and an exceeding comfort to all the land.

The Duke of Lineux, the Earle of Arundell, the Earle of Dor≈øet, the Lord Haddindon, with diuers other Barrons of England, and Scotland, afterward, in honour of this magnificent mariage, performed many worthy races, and many times tooke the Ring with much ≈øtrangenes, a plea≈øure ≈øo princely, that it euen made the beholders hearts to leape with ioy.

The Qu√©enes Maie≈øtie, with her daughter the Princes, all the while ≈øtanding in the windowes, as eye-witne≈ø≈øes to the≈øe noble delights, ≈ømiled with much ch√©erefulnes, graciou≈øly thanking them all for their loues, but e≈øpecially the new married Bride, in honour of who≈øe mariage all the≈øe courtly pa≈øtimes were performed.

div.head: Of the Maskes and Reuells pre≈øented by the Gentlemen of the Innes of Court, vpon the Munday night.
div.p: THe proc√©eding Night, ≈øports were as ≈øumptuous, as the pa≈ø≈øed dayes, and in as gallant a manner performed: whereof to ≈øati≈øfie the de≈øirefull Reader, I mu≈øt thus ≈øpeake of.

The Gentlemen of the Innes of Court, in the be≈øt and rare≈øt manner they could deui≈øe, prepared Ma≈økes and Reuells in the Court, that night to be pre≈øented: and about the houres of eight or nine, they pa≈ø≈øed from the Roles in Chancery-Lane, to White Hall, in as royall manner as euer gallants did to the Court of England.

Fir≈øt, there rode ≈øome thr√©e ≈øcore braue ≈øpirited Gentlemen vpon great Bard-hor≈øes, mo≈øt richly trapped with imbrothered
furnitures, them≈øelues attired in cloth of golde and ti≈ø≈øue, mo≈øt gloriou≈øly ≈øhining, lighted by a number of torches, to beautifie the ≈øhowe with more Eye-plea≈øing delights.

After them, ≈øome ≈øixe and thirtie Ma≈økers, diuided by twelues, in mo≈øt ≈øtrange Anticke ≈øutes, in a mo≈øt admirable and ≈øtately manner. Likewi≈øe vpon co≈øtly trapped ≈øt√©edes, each of them hauing a Blackamoore Page attending on Hor≈øe backe, with torch lights burning in their hands.

After them followed thr√©e Charriots of Ma≈økers and Reuellers, in garments of a meruellous fa≈øhion, ≈øo artificially di≈øgui≈øed, that they moued much wonder. Vpon them attended a number of Footemen, bearing burning torches, and withall, many trumpets ≈øounding melodiou≈øly, which was a ≈øight both to Eye and Eare, of an exc√©eding glorie: The≈øe performed many delightfull dances in his Highnes pre≈øence, and other pa≈øtimes of plea≈øure, to the great comfort of all the beholders, and to the high honours of this magnificent Marriage.

div.head: Of the Tryumphs and Reuells vpon the next night following, being Shroue-tue≈øday.
div.p: THe next day being Shroue-tue≈øday, a day of plea≈øure, and Iollitie by cu≈øtome, but farre more delightfull by rea≈øon of this magnificent mariage, which moued many occa≈øions of mirth in his Highnes court, for euery day in ≈øeuerall attires, were the Nobilitie of the land ≈øeene flouri≈øhing in the chamber of pre≈øence, and much was the co≈øt ≈øpent in banqueting of forraigne e≈øtates, as wel Princes Emba≈ø≈øadors, as the P√©eres and Nobles attending vpon the Pal≈øegraue, which vpon this day was as royally performed, as vpon the former.

The bountie of his Maie≈øtie exc√©eded, for his Highnes court was fr√©e for all people of fa≈øhion, as well Cittizens as others, and few came thither that departed without kind entertainement for liberalitie, with ≈øpredding armes kept open hou≈øhold, whereby the time may well be recorded for a time of Princes plea≈øures, by rea≈øon Princes were the maintainers thereof.

The night proc√©eding, much expectation was made of a ≈øtage play to be acted in the great Hall by the Kings Players, where many hundreds of people ≈øtood attending the ≈øame: but it hapned contrarie, for greater plea≈øures were preparing, which in this manner were performed, as vpon the night before a mo≈øt famous ma≈øke came to court, by the Gentlemen and ≈øtudients of the lawe, from the Roles Office, by land, ≈øo ≈øome thr√©e hundred Gentlemen more, of the ≈øame e≈øtate and calling, by water, to equall them in ≈øtatelines, came likewi≈øe vp the Thames by water, with a ma≈øke to White Hall, at who≈øe ≈øetting forth from Winche≈øter-hou≈øe in their Barges, a peale of ordinance placed on the backe≈øide, ≈ø√©emed as it were thunder, the Barges were beautified with many flagges and Streamers, lighted with a number burning cre≈ø≈øets and torches, attended on by Drums and Trumpets, which ≈øounded all the way mo≈øt melodiou≈øly, the Gentlemen and ma≈økers, had mo≈øt glorious and rich ≈øuites of cloth of gold and ≈øiluer, with other Robes of much delight and plea≈øure, their entertainements in Court were gratious, and their performance as curious as the ≈økill and Art of wit could deui≈øe, at which the King and all the royall a≈ø≈øembly there pre≈øent, tooke high contentment.

The Kings Maie≈øtie, in the royaltie of his minde, and in regard of the≈øe rare deui≈øes of the Gentlemen of the Innes of Court, (being mo≈øt of them ≈øonnes to great ≈øtates of the land) inuited them all within few daies after, to a royall banquet, where not onely by his Highnes, but by the Pal≈øegraue and his Bride, they had mo≈øt kind and friendly thankes.

And now to conclude my di≈øcour≈øe, the ioyes hereof were declared in manie places, as well Citie as Court: for the Belles of London rung generally in euery Church, and in euery ≈øtr√©ete Bon-fires blazed abundantly, there was neither co≈øt nor paines ≈øpared by his Highnes ≈øubiects, that any way might giue ≈øignes of ioy, for the Marriage of his princely daughter to her royall Hu≈øband, whom God ble≈ø≈øe with long happines, and Throanes of Angelles k√©epe and defend. Amen.
